text: [MUSIC — TOPAZ JONES, ”WHO?”]
[MUSIC FADES]

“The special effects
on this are crazy!”
“A is for amphetamines.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ JONES,
“AMPHETAMINES”]
“B is for blue.”
[MUSIC — TOPAZ JONES, “BLUE”]
[ECHOING] “No.”
“That’s good working, boy.”
“Aight.
What’s your name?
What’s your basketball name?”
“Uh, they call me Professor.”
“Just Robbie, I guess.”
“Robbie.”
“I’m Benny [INAUDIBLE].”
“What’s your basketball name?”
“My name’s Escalade.”
“What’s your basketball name?”
“Ace.”
“Ace?”

“When I play, they
call me Splash.”
[LAUGHTER]

“It’s pretty obvious.
‘Cause when I shoot —”

“Yeah, ‘cause you’re always
on the floor when people cross
you out.”
[LAUGHTER]
“C is for code switching.”
[MUSIC — TOPAZ JONES, “WHO?”]

[RAPPING] “— that was
blessed with some melanin.

Who am I to be
special and viewed
as some kind of specimen?

Ladies and gentlemen,
expats and residents,

crack pushers and presidents,
Black beauty and excellence.
Who do you think you are?”
“D is for drums.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “BUGGIN’”]

[RAPPING] “The other day,
I saw a spider on my wall.

I watched it crawl to the
center. Thought to myself,

being small looked appealing,
no billing receipts,

just chilling and sleeping,
resting on the windowsill,
creeping.

See, the problem is,
policy ain’t politics.

Always play a role,
no matter where you go
and how you live.

Some play to cut, some
climb, others reclining.

Summertime, none of us
outside when sun is shining.”

“You are now looking at the
face of someone who is about
to graduate.

Tell us, how does it feel to
be graduating after two long
years?”
“Well, it’s exciting.

I can’t believe I
finally made it.”

“Who do you credit to being
able to graduate through
these two years?”
“Well, the list is long.

As they say, I stand on
many people’s shoulders.”
“E is for education.”

“Um, I didn’t really
understand what my education
was like until afterwards.

Until after I got
out of high school

and I started picking
up books on my own

and then finding
out that a lot

of the things I learned in
school were not, in fact, true.

And that did not
sit well with me.

School systems, historically,
have put limitations

on how people can — how
people choose to struggle.

We need to change
the vocabulary
in how we view slavery —

not using the term
“slave” but “enslaved,”

not using “plantations”
but “prison labor camps.”

How we teach it has to change,
because it becomes very —

it eats at a young
child’s person.

You know, Montclair’s
very diverse.

It’s diverse, as far
as race is concerned.

Different minority
groups are here.

But it’s also
diverse in class.

About four years ago,
a group of teachers

got together and created
a group, Teachers Undoing
Racism Now.

We wanted to continue the
conversation about teachers

themselves, looking within
themselves to undo racism

but also start to look
at ways that we can
protect Black and brown kids.

We have a teacher
trip to Washington, D.C.,

to the African American
museum,

and to the Blacks
in Wax Museum.

This year, we’re working with
the superintendent to get

Juneteenth placed
on the calendar,

to take Columbus Day
off the calendar

and replace it with
Indigenous Peoples’ Day.

But also, what we’re looking
at doing is trying to make it

more comfortable for Black
parents and grandparents

to come to the school to
find out about their kids.
All power to the people.

My name is Rodney
Jackson, activist,

social studies teacher at
Renaissance Middle School,
about 20 years.”
“Hi.
Hi.
And there’s Uncle Blake.”
“Hey, what’s up?
Excuse me.”
[LAUGHTER]
“It’s a white Christmas.”

“It’s a white Christmas, with
a bunch of Black people.”
“It’s your boyfriend.”
“Hi, there.”
“Hi!
I messed it up. Sorry!”
[LAUGHTER]
“F is for family.”

“When we was at Motown,
after rehearsal,
everybody went out to eat.

Berry Gordy said everybody
is going bowling.

We sisters came from
Monongahela, Pa.
There was one bowling alley.
Blacks were not allowed.
We didn’t know what to do.

We had never been inside
of a bowling alley before.

My mother always taught us,
if you don’t know what to do,
be a good listener.”
“G is garden.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “HERRINGBONE”]

[RAPPING] “We ain’t gotta
explain it to people that
don’t love us.

The blues is mo’ better,
food is mo’ butter.”
“My name is Frances.
I use “she”/“they.”

I’m a Black Puerto Rican
from the South Bronx.

I am an urban farm worker
and a community organizer.

Yeah, it is weird for us to
just see our food, right?

We go to the supermarket,
and the food is there,

but we aren’t really having
a conversation or taking

into consideration or
even acknowledging all

of the Black and brown people
at every point of the food

system who can’t even
afford the food that they’re
growing.
It’s not a food desert.

It’s actually food apartheid,
because it’s intentional.

It’s not just a natural thing
that Black and brown and poor

and overpoliced neighborhoods
also don’t have access

to fresh food, to
affordable fresh food,
foods that are nutrient-dense.
It’s calculated.

It’s the people in
power who are deciding,

the people in power who make
money off of our sickness.

So I think it’s important
for us to pan out from

the individual and really
look at the institutional,

the structural racism that’s
happening that makes it

so that people in
power, the politicians,

will get to decide
the rezoning.
Right?

It’s really important to see
the inaccess to fresh food

as an apartheid, as a
calculated thing that is

being put in place by
the people in power.
Woke Foods is a woman-run, food-service-worker-owned
cooperative.

So right off the bat,
we’re a worker-owned co-op.

We are not a traditional,
hierarchical, oppressive
business structure.

So we’re thinking about,
how do we shop locally?

How do we eat food
that’s seasonal,

so that we’re not
participating in this food

system that brings food
from all over the country?

By the time it gets to us,
it’s already starting to die.

We need to pan out
a little further

and know how to
grow all the food
and be able to support people.

And not even just learning
how to grow the food

but how to remember
how to grow food.

Because a lot of us, we have
this information within us.

If all that is stripped away
and we’re just human beings

on this planet, like, what’s
going to be my contribution?
H is for herringbone.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “HERRINGBONE”]

“I is for
intellectual property.

I guess for me, the time
at which I began to come

into the understanding of the
value of my own intellectual

property was around the time
that I experienced, you know,

what it felt like to have that
sort of taken away

or to have that, you know, property
in someone else’s hands.

I’m often asked, you know, what
advice I would give to young

people or upstarts in the
industry, young creatives.

And, you know, what I
always say off the bat is

to maintain ownership
of that property,

of your intellectual
property, of your art,
for as long as possible.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “MIRROR”]

[SINGING] “Tell me who
the realest of them all.”
“J is for jealousy.”
“K is for karma.”

“Jaki Graham with ‘Set
Me Free’ and also

Curt and Starleana, otherwise
known as Aurra,
and ‘You and Me Tonight.’”

[SINGING] “I may not be
the man that I want to be,

but I’m sure not the
man that I used to be.”
“L is for language.”

“My relationship with
language is always going to be
an assertion.

So I’m asserting my right
to be within the world,

I’m asserting that my
perspective has value,

and I’m asserting my
existence in a lot of ways.

What drew me to writing is
reading and experiencing

so much beautiful
art and realizing

that there are a million
ways to tell a story.

I think that we’re often told
that there’s only one way.

So either we’re told that
there’s only one way to tell

a story or there’s only
one story worth being told.

And both of those
things are lies, so.

Code switching is so ingrained
in Black folks in the South,

because we’re living in
relatively segregated areas.

And then in addition to that,
because, you know, upward

mobility is a goal
of all, you know,

the Black middle
class and whatnot —

your parents try to get you
in spaces that are different
than where you’re from.

And in doing so,
you have to learn
how to go back and forth.

I sound different
when I’m at home.

[CHUCKLE] Like, my
accent gets deeper.

Because you probably
don’t hear anything now,
but my accent reanimates. My diction changes

because certain words don’t
make sense or don’t mean

the same things here
that they do there.

What was beautiful about being
in Philly as a young adult,

as a young person, was
experiencing so much

of life outside
of the classroom.

Philly is a
decidedly Black city.

Experiencing, particularly,
Philly’s poetry scene helped

to, like, buoy that spirit of
ingenuity and authenticity.

Philly’s also going to
tell you if you [EXPLETIVE].

The beautiful thing
about being Black

is, like, learning
new dialects

and learning new ways of
existing in the world.

Like, there’s no way that
I would be using the word

“jawn” if I didn’t
live in Philly.

“Jawn” is a beautiful word
because it’s so expansive.

Black voices bend
around the word.

Like, all of these slight
changes to, like, something
that is, to us, universal.
You know, it’s beautiful.
My name is Ivy Sole.

I’m originally from
Charlotte, N.C.

I am a nonbinary femme human,
using “she”/“they” pronouns,
and I am happy to be alive.”
“M is for mirror.”

“You’re not being your real
self in a lot of situations,

and that breeds
resentment and bitterness,
and now you’re take [EXPLETIVE] out on people
who haven’t done anything to you, you know.

Because of how you
feel about yourself.”
“N is for nappy.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “BUGGIN’”]

[RAPPING] “I must be
buggin’, gotta be buggin’,
buggin’ out.
I’m buggin’ out.
I’m buggin’ out.”
“My name is Keith White.
I’m an attorney by trade.

I do civil rights,
federal litigation,

criminal and civil, as well
as intellectual property.

I’m an advocate, activist and
father and husband, you know,
and all the things.”
“Where are you from?”
“I’m from Brownsville.

I’m from the Brownsville
section of Brooklyn.

I lived in Brownsville for
the first 28 years of my life.

I had never been in a white
space before law school.

I had grew up in Brownsville. I
went to school at John Jay,

with a bunch of other
minoritized members
of my community.
I went to church.

Like, I was in all of
these Black spaces.

It was not until
law school that I

was in this white
space, and I felt
enraged to say something.

When I was in law school,
Amadou Diallo was shot,

and there were 41 shots
fired into his vestibule.
He was unarmed.

And when I went to school
and I tried to talk about it,
there was silence.

There was, like, a
deafening silence around it.

The next day, I
went to school.

I had a white T-shirt, and I
wrote, “41 shots,” in red ink.

If no one’s going
to talk about it,

I’m going make everyone
as uncomfortable as I am.

So it wasn’t necessarily
organizing in the sense that

we think about, but it was the
first time that I felt like I

needed to say something
about something that happened

to my community,
in my community

and no one else was talking
about in a white space.

We decided to come together
and collectively become

the Bklyn Combine, because
we saw a void in community.

And we wanted to create
that for ourselves,

and we wanted to create
that for the larger
community around us.

And so that’s really what
the Bklyn Combine is.

So we get together, and we
provide mentoring services

in Red Hook, Brownsville,
East New York and Bed-Stuy.

We also provide
advocacy services.

Like, a couple of
weeks ago, a few guys
were sitting on my stoop.

They were working on
the building next door.

They were sitting on my
stoop, some Black guys.

I opened the door, and
they immediately jumped up,

and they were like,
“Oh, my bad, my bad.’

You know, like,
‘Sorry, sorry, sorry.’
And I was like, ‘No, no, no.
Y’all can sit.
Y’all want something to drink?
What’s your names?
I’m just checkin’ in.
I’m seeing how y’all doing.’

And the tenor of
the conversation

completely changed,
from something

that could have been
antagonistic to community.

And I think that a lot
of times, white people

haven’t just been programmed
to think negatively
about Black interaction.
We’ve been taught.
We’ve been programmed.

How we start seeing —
how we see each other

is really incredibly
important.

If we start spending more
time revolutionizing concepts

and principles of liberation
and freedom within ourselves,

it allows us to go out and
organize with folks that are

outside of our immediate
perspective, you know.”
[CAR HONKING]
[LAUGHTER]

[SINGING] “Buggin’
out, y’all.”

[RAPPING] “This
grown man talkin’.

Don’t go tellin’ your
momma, don’t go runnin’ up

in the house like you’re
scared of a monster.

Stick your chin up. Go do
some chin-ups. You’re skinny.

I hope she finna make
spinach for dinner.

Under your skin,
like a splinter.

At night, I dream about living
above the rim like a spinner.

But chances I make the league
are gettin’ slimmer than

a Jim or Eminem
or Kendall Jenner,

rival of Pepsi spread
all on her dresser.
America, God.”
“P is for play-fight.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ JONES,
“HERRINGBONE,”]

[SINGING] “Got a smile
like your momma’s.

Can’t keep a woman if
you can’t keep a promise.
I used to act so shady.
Baby, least I’m being honest.

All of my aunties
throwing shade like, uh.

All of my uncles
playing spades like, ah.

Tears in my eyes
when we play-f —”
“Q is for questions.”
“Oh.”
“Um, do you think he’s real?”
“Mm.”
“We don’t know yet.”
“I don’t know.”
“I don’t know.”
“I don’t know.”
“R is for rich.”
“We can start now.”
“We can start now?”

“Yeah, let’s just, kind of,
feel one out and see how it
feels.”

“OK. You know, what I
wanted you to know about some
of our family history —

your father’s grandfather
was a very stubborn man,

and his name was
Marshall Jones.

He had all this land, and
his main crop was cotton.

And he planted
all this cotton.

And when the harvest time
came, he got the cotton

and put it in
bales and had it

stacked all around the
house and in the yard.

And it was ready to go
to market to go to sell.

And he wouldn’t sell, and all
of the farmers and even his

sons told him, you
gotta sell, you know,

because they are predicting
a rainy season.

He said, I’m not selling,
because we’re going to wait
for the price to go up.

So he was a very
stubborn old man.

And he thought he knew better
than anybody else, you know.

It didn’t go up, but the rain
came down and destroyed all
of his cotton.
He lost a fortune then.

And then he started
trying to recoup.

He sold some of his land and
made a few other bad business
deals, you know.

And my husband always said,
if his grandfather had done

the right thing, had sold the
cotton when it should have

been sold, all of us would
have been in a better

position and would
have been wealthy.”
[MUSIC — TOPAZ JONES, “RICH”]

[SINGING] “I be
spending like I’m rich.

I be frontin’ like
I’m broke sometimes.”
“Look at this.”
[LAUGHTER]
“S is for sour belts.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “SOURBELTS”]
[RAPPING] “— pictures I lost.

All of them fingers I
crossed, all of them
wishes I tossed in the well.
I need a ride from my pops.
I need to buy some eyedrops.

Peace of mind, piece of
pie, can’t even sleep.
I cyclops quite a lot.

Blindfoldin’ origami, order
sushi, pourin’ sake out.

Gorgeous view from the
roof, more confusions
from your cotton mouth.

Easter eggs turnin’ rotten
now. Throwin’ toilet paper,
porta potty mouth.

Made the morning paper, can’t
afford to save a single cent.

Countin’ every second
like this ain’t for rent.

Momma said I don’t
know how to act.

Over my shorty
crib after school,

keys jingle Kris
Kringle out the back.

Never understood how
a fat [EXPLETIVE] made it

down the chimney
in the first place.

My first taste of lust came
laced inside a honey dutch.

We was watching Bubbles,
Blossom, Buttercup.

Can’t lose my mojo,
brain was too loco.

I’m bangin’ with Weezy, the
pain in his vocals remind me
of Stevie.

I’m steamin’ like cocoa. It’s
almost a quarter to three.

Yeah, uh, do you still
got the quarter for cheap?
Yeah.
Why blame it on my maker?
Won’t save my from my nature.

Won’t shade me from
this rainfall.”
“T is for time.”

“You’re shining like a
Siberian dog, bro.”
“Like a —”
[CHUCKLE]

“You like the broke
version of Cap'n Crunch.”

“You look like a
pubic hair brusher.”
[CHUCKLE]
“You know it’s lit.
You know it’s lit.”
“What time is it?”
“Time for you get a watch.”
[BUZZING NOISE]
“Where did he go?”
“Say I don’t know, bro.
His mother don’t play.
[INAUDIBLE]
“Fo sho.”
“U is for underground.”
[SILENT]
“Hi.”
“Hello.

How do I relate to
people opening up to me?
I look at it as an honor.

What I do as a therapist
is, kind of, like a midwife.

So I’m holding people’s hand
as they’re laboring and going

through some of the
most challenging things
in their lives.

How I became a
therapist is kind of
a winding road of a story.

But long story short, in
2009, I was Miss New Jersey,

and went on to the
Miss USA pageant,

and I experienced
a lot of criticism

just being on that
platform, a lot

of anxiety and
perfectionism and things
that I had to work through.

So through that experience,
and also talking to a lot

of millennials that compare
themselves a lot to other

people, compare
themselves to their peers,
I know what it’s like.

And it makes me
more empathetic,
because I’ve been on that end.

And not even from
that experience,

though, just being human, like you
know what it’s like to feel
criticized.

You know what it’s like
to be picked apart.

You know what it’s like to
wonder, am I good enough?

It’s this idea that
if you’re in therapy,
you must be crazy.

But that’s not
what therapy is.

It’s really a
form of self-care.
Some of it is cultural.

You know, for Black
people, in particular,

there’s this idea of ‘We
keep things in the family
and in the home.’

And letting someone else
that’s not in the family

into your personal issues —
that’s not what we do.

Let’s say, speaking
for my own family.

I think that there
are a lot of members

of my family,
older members, that

are more hesitant to
participate in therapy, even

though they might clearly need
it, because of the stigma.

But I think working with
a culturally competent

therapist that understands
the value of family

and understands
the role that that

plays in how you show up in
therapy is really important.

In more recent years,
in the past maybe

two years or so, there’s
been a shift in the Black

community around
mental health.

All of that has
driven, you know,

more Black people to finding
therapists that look like

them, and it’s
been a great thing.

I think we all need to
be able to do that and be
vulnerable.”

“Ladies and gentlemen,
whatever your take on this

piece of art is, it’s
still a piece of art.”
“W is for world star.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “D.O.A.”]

[RAPPING] “I got wanted
posters all over the block.

How you ’posed to pose for
the photos when ops takin’
the shots?
Got ’em open with the bars.
Don’t end up over the rocks.

You [EXPLETIVE] sweet, probably
belong in a cocktail
with some schnapps.

School of hard knocks, all the
lessons, I won’t forget it.

My energy so kinetic,
my enemies so pathetic.

They stealin’ my
whole aesthetic.
I’m keepin’ it copacetic.

And that’s only the tip
of the frozen lettuce.

I remember gettin’
rotten tomatoes.”
“World star!”
“X is for Xerox.”

“You have the
rituals of family.

[INAUDIBLE] They
wanted their boy
to carry on the family name.

And then, what was so amazing
is that my son had a son,
and —”

“Your daughter
had a daughter!”
[LAUGHTER]

“And you take all the kids
in the [INAUDIBLE] one hour
a day to swim.”
“Y is for yard.”
[LAWNMOWER BUZZING]
[MUSIC PLAYING FAINTLY]
[TAPS ON TAMBOURINE]
“Hey.
How much?”
“You can just keep that.”
“For real?”
“Thank you.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “BLACK TAME”]

[SINGING] “I really
wanna be your lover.”
“Z is for ZIP code.”

“This is for the South End,
the 4-4, Uptown, Frog Hollow,

the Six Corners, the six
square miles that once held
my universe.

Showing my cousins how
the computer works,

the alphabet for
all the poker chips.
This time, I ante up.
It’s time I ran it up.

This trauma can’t be
overdramatized for white

critics to verify
if he’s authentic.

This is for Jefferson’s
Cafe, the Wood Pit,

Crockett’s Fish Fry,
sweet potato with pecans,

we swore up and down they
sprinkle crack cocaine
in the yam sauce.

Never too much,
Luther Vandross, me

and my insecurities
in a Mexican standoff.

But, [EXPLETIVE], who
else could avenge

the death of every little
saint in the dance-off?

This is for DJ Jayhood,
Unique, DJ Frosty, DJ Little

Man and, of course, the
legendary Tim D-D-Dollar
Dollar.

To this day, my heart probably
beats at 130 b.p.m. if a young

lady shows to throw it, then
my friends have my back,
so it wouldn’t bend.

Oh, see, y’all had to be
there to even comprehend.

This is the Lackawanna
Plaza, the Mecca, the casa.

Against all odds, I
got my first white tee

while my Ma bought
crab legs and Pathmark.

Y’all can go ahead,
tear it down,

and give the people a Trader
Joe’s if you want to now.
It’s OK. It’s immortalized.
This is for my fam.
This is for the tribe.
This is fortified.
This is forever.
This is for God.
And 07042, this is for you.
Who am I?”
“I love you.”
“See you later, honey.
I love you, too.”
“Bye.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “MIRROR”]

“Ladies and gentlemen,
pimps and prophets,

queens and dope fiends,
hoes and hoteps,

we got somethin’ to discuss
with you tonight, folks.

Everybody from Uptown to the
South End makin’ their way
on down to Lackawanna Plaza.”

[RAPPING] “I think I’m
finally finding me.

My whole life, it’s
been hide-and-seek.
I used to suffer in silence.

I never showed you
that side of me.
Hypnotized by society.”

[MUSIC — TOPAZ
JONES, “D.I.A.L.”]
“(SINGING) Money, yeah.
Money to be made.
And I just want it right now.
Please get down or lie down.

When I’m in the grave, I
need everything iced out.
Dying is a lifestyle.
Money to be made.
And I just want it right now.
Please get down or lie down.

When I’m in the grave, I
need everything iced out.
Dying is a lifestyle.

Told you I was going to
beat your ass one day.
One day.
Please hold me back.
I’ma slap him in his face.

He touched my girlfriend,
that’s disrespect.

I swung. He ducked and
pushed me through the desk.
Why all this drama?

You know my momma,
been to my casa.

When we were young,
you were the golden,
the child I should copy.

Everyone said to be like
[INAUDIBLE] problems
with you. Look, I do not want.

But I am a man,
so I gotta flaunt.
Or they gonna call me a punk.

This morning I
bought me a pump.
I’m cycling through memories.
Hindsight is 20/20 clean.
Now you got me backpedaling.
Psychiatrist not helping me.

Your childhood
not so heavenly.

There’s hell to
pay, my L to take.
I make it through.
I celebrate.
Why sell an eight?
There’s money to be made.
And I just want it right now.
Please get down or lie down.

When I’m in the grave, I
need everything iced out.”
